author: Eleanor Doughty
title: Things you'll remember if you grew up in the 70s
text: A lot was packed into the 1970s - a decade of questionable hairstyles, lots of brown, and a dash or two of musical genius. But which bits do you remember best? These are some of the defining moments of the 70s, in all their glory. The Beatles split up, and your life was over The Beatles together in the 1970s Photo: Alamy The decade kicked off with The Beatles ' announcement that they had split up in April 1970, forcing a whole generation of pop-lovers to go into mourning. Some speculated that the reason for the split was spurred on by the death of Brian Epstein , their fearless promoter, while others blamed George Harrison's growth as a composer. The UK changed its currency altogether The half penny was introduced in 1971 Photo: Alamy 15 February 1971 became known as Decimal Day , the day that the United Kingdom and Ireland decimalised their currencies. In 'old money', with pounds, shillings and pence, the pound was made up of 240 pence (or 240d). There were 12 pence in a shilling, and 20 shillings (20s) in a pound. But you knew that already, because you were there. A woman finally became Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher became the first female Prime Minister in 1979 Photo: Rex Conservative MP Margaret Thatcher rose to power in 1979 - the first of three elections she would go on to win. And just before she did, a little industrial action had angered the country The Winter of Disconcent included binmen strikes Photo: Rex A series of strikes by public sector trade unions became known as the Winter of Discontent, and occurred over the winter of 1978-9. These included binmen, ambulance services and, unofficially, grave-diggers. You could suddenly get to America in three hours The Concorde on its first flight from London Photo: AP The Concorde was introduced in 1976, and was the first supersonic air transport to be entered into commercial service. Super fast, it could reach New York in just under three and a half hours - half the time of a regular jet. After a devastating crash in 2000, it was taken out of use in 2003. A lot of men had crazy hair... Kevin Keegan: long hair and sideburns were all the rage Photo: Getty It was long, bushy and often came with a moustache. And sideburns. Footballer Kevin Keegan gave good hair back then. ...including the Glam Rockers... Slade epitomised the glam rock scene in the 1970s Photo: Rex Slade had everything the 70s required of them: the hair, the flares and the glitter. And a spot on Top of the Pops . Bingo. ...and ABBA. Say no more ABBA: Sweden's greatest export Photo: Alamy The Swedish pop band made the 70s their Waterloo, and Knowing Me, Knowing You, you remember them just as well as the next 70s teenager. Some of your musical idols died, which broke your heart Elvis Presley died in 1977 Photo: Rex The 70s wasn't a great decade for pop star mortality: Janis Joplin died from a heroin overdose in 1970, Jimi Hendrix died a month earlier, and then Elvis Presley was found dead in 1977. But luckily, children's TV was great Oliver Postgate's The Clangers: cult children's television Photo: Smallfilms The Clangers , The Magic Roundabout , Mr Benn , and Bagpuss were just a few of the brilliant cult children's television programmes that graced our screens. They just don't make them like that anymore, do they? The Silver Jubilee cheered things up a bit in 1977 The Queen greets the crowds at her Silver Jubilee celebrations Photo: Hulton Archive 1977 was a big year for royal celebration. The Sex Pistols released their famous 'God Save The Queen', everyone had a street party , village bonzanza, or turned out in London to watch Queen Elizabeth II walk down The Mall. Even though everything was brown and orange The world was a much browner place Photo: Alamy And matching. Wallpaper, bedding, cushions - the lot. All brown, and often orange too. Including the cars, which were boxes on wheels The Ford Cortina was a classic 70s car - and came in brown Photo: Alamy The Ford Cortina was one of the best-selling cars of the decade - and even came in brown. But you always had Jackie Magazine to comfort you. Good old Jackie Photo: DC Thomson & Co telegraph.co.uk Follow @telegoodlife
